basics.name: Matías G. Villalba
basics.label: Economist
basics.summary: Undergraduate student majoring in Economics at Universidad del Pacífico (Perú) expected to graduate on july 2024. Currently in my final semester having already successfully defended my thesis and completed heavy coursework.

work.name: Centro de Investigación de la Universidad del Pacífico (CIUP)
work.summary: Assisted with the development of a randomized control trial studying the effect of homophily on academicoutcomes within student social networks.
highlights: Designed and conducted baseline and endline surveys, critical for the project’s data collection.
Utilized Stata for rigorous cleaning and analysis of survey and large administrative datasets (+250k observations).
Created comprehensive tables in LaTeX, along with insightful figures.

work.name: George Mason University and Inter-American Development Bank
work.summary: Assisted with multiple concurrent projects in political economy, primarily focusing on impact evaluation studiesanalyzing the effects of extreme COVID-19 policies in Colombia and Chile.
highlights: Utilized Stata and Python for web-scraping and complex data cleaning of massive government datasets (+2Mobservations).
Used OCR tools in Python for large-scale text extraction.
Fine-tuned and applied LLM for systematic entity identification and extraction, crucial to the project's methodology

publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.
